meaning: The word 'afternoon' refers to the period of time between noon and evening, typically from 12:00 PM to around 6:00 PM. It is the part of the day following the morning and preceding the evening.
etymology: The word 'afternoon' originates from Middle English, combining 'after' (from Old English 'æfter') and 'noon' (from Old English 'nōn', meaning the ninth hour of the day, approximately 3 PM). Over time, 'noon' shifted to mean 12 PM, and 'afternoon' came to denote the time following noon.
homophone_word: None. 'Afternoon' does not have a perfect homophone, but it may sound similar to phrases like 'after noon' when spoken quickly.
sentence: She spent the entire afternoon reading her favorite book.
The sun was shining brightly in the afternoon sky.
As the famous quote by Henry James goes, 'Summer afternoon—summer afternoon; to me those have always been the two most beautiful words in the English language.'
short_stories: In a small village, an old man would sit on his porch every afternoon, watching the children play. One day, a curious child asked him why he always smiled in the afternoon. He replied, 'Because the afternoon reminds me of the warmth of life and the joy of simple moments.'
A young artist found inspiration during a quiet afternoon by the lake. The golden light reflecting on the water inspired her to paint her most famous masterpiece, titled 'Afternoon Serenity.'
poetry: From 'Afternoon on a Hill' by Edna St. Vincent Millay: 'I will be the gladdest thing under the sun! I will touch a hundred flowers and not pick one.'
From 'The Afternoon Sun' by C.P. Cavafy: 'This room, how well I know it. Now they’re renting it, and the one next to it, as offices.'
